description:
Situation
- Drinks with friends Friday evening before going to the nearby movie theatre

Feedback
- All the bartenders that work there are great
- There are a handful of TV's with sports
- The mixed drinks are pretty decent
- There are only 4 beers on tap
author: Dipesh G.

description: This place is a decent bar and has a great bartender who is friendly and welcoming. It's always busy here and we usually play pool in the back. They have one table and it's a dollar a game. Drinks are solid and all around fun place for a casual drink in the area
author: Anna J.

description:
On the scale of dive bars, Philosopher's Club is on the higher end. It actually has a cool theme, stiff drinks, and great parking/location.

Got a drink before watching a movie for date night. We both agreed we would get a beer next time. Our drinks weren't the tastiest, but they were strong. Props to our bartender. I was craving a whiskey sour and bae got an old-fashioned. But we both agreed they tasted on the sweeter side. I was disappointed, but should've KNOWN that the sour would've been a pre-made mix. Ah well. Next time I'll get a kamikaze or a well drink. Although the selection on tap is slim (think VERY BASIC like Blue Moon and Red Trolley), they do have a wider selection of alcohol vs beer. 

In terms of the service, I give it a BIG 5 stars. AWESOME bar staff. There were two guys taking care of the entire bar, and they were so welcoming and friendly. I definitely don't always feel comfortable as an Asian girl at someone else's local watering hole, so I really appreciated how friendly and smiley the guys were. They were playing the Warriors game, which is mainly why most people were there. There are lots of seating options from tall bar stools to high tops and tables in the back. The place is cozy and inviting, not dingy and smelly like wet carpet. 

I'd definitely come back if in the area!
author: Jodi H.

description: Dropped in for a cocktail with my sister and loved the local vibe. Deb the bartender was friendly and the drink was good.
author: Lars B.

description: Wish I could give this racist bar 0 stars. I asked the female bartender for a sex on the beach. She responded in a rude matter and with a mad face and body language and said, "I can't make that right now." So then I said okay one moment so I can figure out what I want. She then walked away very angry. She walked over to another bartender and was telling him the story with her hands all in the air mad. Like okay my bad for asking a bartender to make a drink. 10 minutes later my boyfriend went and asked another bartender for a sex on the beach and the bartender makes it no problems at all. So why couldn't that lady make it, I have no clue. Then about a hour later I seen the lady outside the bar talking to a group of ladies, and what is she talking to the ladies about, ME!! Telling them the story of me asking her to make me a sex on the beach. And her telling me no she couldn't and the ladies laughing and saying yeah and she probably would of only tipped you a dollar and the lady saying yeah. Moral of the story is don't go to this bar unless you're a white local regular.
author: tatiana f.

description:
This place used to be good. Nice tables and average at worst beer selection make it an easy option. Easy restroom, etc.

I have to say the staff is pretty grouchy these days for some reason. I understand maybe charging for water if it's busy and someone is by themself or maybe a couple, but to a pregnant lady is a group of 6 paying customers on a Sunday night with like 3 other patrons. Really?
author: David A.

description:
What an excellent establishment!   Such a welcoming environment and get ready for this....bartenders who actually enjoy their job and are happy to pour you a beer or make a drink!  We popped in to watch the Warriors take game six and wound up high fiving complete strangers who wanted to make sure that we were welcome at their local spot.
It was a great night out.  SF is still so full of surprises and this place is one of them.
Guys--don't change a thing--you're good people.
author: Thomas D.

description: Philosopher's Club is an old-school San Francisco neighborhood bar. Reasonably priced drinks. Friendly service. Lots of SF and Giants memorabilia, including a photo of Playland at the Beach. Worth a trip to see the ceiling painting of various philosophers though time to the present day. Not quiet but you can have a conversation there, good for an after-work get together. Good show!
author: Charles B.

description: Having a frothy beer piss into a trough that looks like it should be used for feeding cattle is the #1 reason to go here. I deducted a star for the absence of a measuring mirror behind the trough but otherwise found my drinking experience monumentally rewarding.  No food, lots of kitschy sports crap on the walls and a hint of Boston Irish to the place.
author: Mark J.

description: Excellent dive bar. Long time local spot, simple place. No food. One pool table. Come here for drinks, not fancy ass cocktails. A couple TVs showing sports. Awesome mural on ceiling.
author: Sam A.

description: Ok so Josh is no longer my fiancée cuz he's my brother so it's actually embarrassing to read that now. But anyway, obviously Philly is the coolest bar in the city: they have that golf Nintendo game, pool table, backyard with a tv, cool bartenders, sweet jackets, cool mural on the ceiling, they sell chips, I mean, what else is there? Don't go here cuz I'm a kermudgen and I don't want u crowding up my bar too much, but just know that's it's cool.
author: Emma H.

description:
Everyone loves The Philly Club - Fun and chill place to pop in for a pop. We often jump off the K Car and drop on and then continue downtown...a tradition! Tons of old locals grace the place...it is like old home week...a "Cheers" wannabe
Bartenders are a hoot. Did I mention cocktails are a bargain? They are.
author: Kae D.

description: Best bar in West Portal hands down! Super friendly staff and moderate prices. Beer, wine, and strong cocktails. They play awesome music most of the time and they have a little patio in the back for smoking. It usually doesn't get too crowded here, but on holidays or game nights it can be hard to find a seat. They sell bags of nuts and chips for one dollar. Other than that, no food for sale. However, you can bring your own food inside!
author: Crystal R.

description: I really like going to this place it has an old vintage feel vibe. I can grab a drink, watch a game, shoot some pool, chill in the back until 10pm and there's an ATM. I would go back when I get the chance.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Very nice place to spend New Years Eve.  Four of us hung out at a table from 10-1.  It was very good energy in there.  Youngish crowd.  Festive.  Had NYE shows and sports on.  They seemed fine with outside food. 

Limited tap beer selection, but my table enjoyed their simple well cocktails.  Seemed to be strong pours. 

No champagne at midnight.  Guess I should have expected that, but I was a tad disappointed.  Only one bartender in service. 

I would definitely return.
author: Joseph B.

description:
So, you looking for a drink in the West Portal area? But you don't want to walk far from a MUNI station? I know a place that should satisfy those needs. The Philosopher's club is at a superb location, next to the West Portal station, which probably explains why it's been there so long. As soon as you walk through those heavy doors you can feel time stop. There is a full wall decorated with old photos of San Francisco, mostly showing the construction of West Portal. And if you look above you can find a mural of brilliant philosophers watching over as you drink, from Bob Dylan to Gandhi, they got the them all.
The drinks are standard, nothing really fancy. There's a jukebox, and a pool table in the back. Like I sad, nothing fancy. Cool place to hangout, away from the clubs and the mess that is downtown.
Have one on me...not really.
author: Joel G.

description:
Philly's is a neighborhood bar.  It's an older bar which got a facelift a few years ago so it's no longer the uber-divey one you might remember, so the prices might not be, either.  But you who are reading this, have you been to West Portal lately?  What are you doing here looking for a dive bar?  It's a nice neighborhood with several wine bars and restaurants and even a movie theater.  I don't think there's a single dive bar in this area!

But I digress.  Say the MUNI is broken that day (It usually is, the switch at the West Portal station always undergoing some kind of repair or another) and you need a spot to wait for a half hour.  Say you got fired or are otherwise having a terrible day.  You wander into the Philosopher's Club, and it's going to be dark.  There's going to be a regular playing the golf game in the corner, another couple of regulars warming their seats at the bar.  Depending on the day another couple of regulars are playing pool in the back.  Someone (Deb or Sully or whomever else is manning the bar) will greet you with a warm welcome.  On the counter there will inevitably be a couple of glasses of alcohol with coasters on them-- some other folks probably went outside for a smoke or went to go get some food (Philly's has no kitchen so you have all of the options of West Portal to choose from).

So let's say you sit down.  If this is your first time, they'll ask you what you'd like to drink.  If it's your second time in here they'll remember what you had last time and ask if you want it again.  If you're a regular they'll have the drink ready for you before you sit down.  Check out a game on the TV's, sit, relax, take in the jovial conversations around you, and take the time to realize that your life isn't that bad, sitting here.

This being a neighborhood bar EVERYONE in here is a regular.  If you are not, a regular will strike up a conversation with you, (or not, if you want to be left alone they're good about that too), and you'll become a regular in no time.  Folks who come back like it because it's their second home, and it's why i keep coming back; everyone's welcome here.  If a neighborhood bar is NOT what you're looking for then this isn't your place.  There are other divier, cheaper places to get blackout drunk.  But why would you want to do that here, anyway, sitting amongst friends?
author: Iris N.

description:
This is the best bar in West Portal, and one of the best in the city.

The prices are great and so is the location.  It is right near the West Portal station and great places to eat like Bullshead and Spiazzo.  

It is an excellent spot to watch the Warriors and Giants, play a game of pool, hang out on the outdoor patio, or hear your favorite song on the internet jukebox.  

The bartenders are great and some of the best in the business.  Deb and Josh provide stiff drinks and great entertainment.
author: Gabrielle W.

description: Great drinks at an unbelievable price!!! We had a gin and tonic and an old fashion for just $10!!!  The atmosphere is great  and the bartenders were super friendly. We will definitely be back soon snd you should too! Check it out!
author: Maria L.

description:
Ugh!! What a disappointment. 
When I dated a guy in the hood in 2001, this was our go-to dive bar. 
I haven't been to it since before they remodeled, but it seems to have become  opportunistic because of all the money in SF. 
$5.50 for A BOTTLE of Newcastle? 
$6 for Trumer on tap? 
Also, though I'm NOT a hipster, I enjoy my PBR and they didn't even HAVE that (though  they had like 15 beers in bottles).
WTF? 
Never again--for those prices I will go to a douchy hipster bar on Valencia!!
author: D C.

description: Great bartenders with a great atmosphere. Great for watching a game or having a beer while you relax on the patio with wonderful regulars or the amazing staff from day shift to evening.  Deb (during the day) is particularly amazing and having drinks with the hospitable Josh and Sully on a Friday night is hard to beat! Come here for a relaxing, good time with great people and great bartenders. You will return!
author: Shannon C.

description: Great neighborhood bar. Great selection, good crowd, comfortable setting, and Josh holds down the fort like a pro.
author: Chris H.

description:
For what it is, and what it aims to do, The Philly Club deserves 5 stars.

I was introduced to this gem by my college roommate, a SF native. This bar SCREAMS old-school San Francisco and has a community of very dedicated regulars of all ages (literally - I've run into friends of my friends' parents). Decorations include old black and white photographs of SF over the years in addition to tons of Giants, Niners, and other local sports memorabilia (including high schools). This is a bar that can serve nearly any type of drinker's need. I've seen people alone at the bar in daylight with a shot and a beer, engaged in deep conversations with the bartender, I've seen the bar go from empty to packed with rowdy fans after a Niners game, I've partaken in pre (and post)-St. Patrick's Day parade festivities, and I've probably most enjoyed my time there on Sunday afternoons.

My recommendation: start with the great Bloody Mary's (can be made extra spicy), and after a few, switch to draft beer and catch up with a friend while watching a Giants game. Often times there's a free community potluck going on on Sundays near the back of the bar. They're cash only, but they have an ATM right in front, drinks are cheap, and trust me, you'll need the cash anyways after a few drinks when the jukebox starts calling your name.

Textbook example of a "come as you are" type establishment - everyone is welcomed here.
author: Laura H.

description: When I'm in West Portal I feel transported to suburban Philly or something. Definitely a chill Cheers kinda vibe of a place. My Manhattan was not delicious (I wanted more bitters I think), but it was cheap and plentiful. Cozy bar stool and big, wide bar, made it easy to linger a while.
author: Andrew K.

description: A bar that makes you feel welcome in SF? Yes please! I've said it before and I'll say it again, if you like cool/trendy, stay far, far away...
author: Makena O.

description: My friend and I had a great time at the  philosophers club last night. I was trying to take a picture of the mural on the ceiling.  The owner, Sully, introduced himself, came around the bar to greet us, told us that his wife painted the mural, and gave us postcard/poster versions of that ceiling mural to take home with us. This is a great bar because Philosophers Club  is really casual.  I'll be back to hang out again soon. The bartenders are friendly and constantly generated a lot of laughter from everyone at the bar last night. I gave five stars because I'll consider this a go-to hangout spot where I would recommend my friends to go to.
author: Evan C.

description:
Right next to West Portal Metro Station and this place is great for meeting up friends, catching up with people or if you're weird like me, order a few drinks and slowly sip on them while reading a book. 

Decor is a bit rustic but the people here are friendly. There are pool tables in the back and free wifi too. ;)
author: Jason C. J.

description: Fun and cool bar to stop by from time to time when I'm in the neighborhood.  The staff is cool and friendly.  The energy of the crowd is good too.
author: Liz D.

description: This is a neighborhood joint that attracts the Sf Catholic school alumni. The bartenders are super friendly and the bar is spacious with a few pool tables in the back.
author: Anastasia P.

description: My husband and I used to love this place, especially on our way home from downtown and Giants games. $6- for a pint of beer, though? No thanks.
author: Ali W.

description:
I enjoy hittin up "the Philly" after getting off the Street Car at WP station. The bartenders are friendly and there's enough TV's going to keep me occupied while I sip my beverage.

You can come here with friends or alone and always feel at home.

Excellent spot for Pre/Post-gaming for Giants games. Lot's of memorabilia on the walls and counters.

CASH ONLY

Cheers!
author: Justin C.

description:
One of my favorite bar in the neighborhood and the best part is it's all locals who go there. I have been going there for years now and it has just been great. 

They even let you bring food from outside so that's def. a plus. I go there to go play pool and I have met some really cool people there. The vibe is very local too so it is really cozy being there. There are like 4 or 5 TVs in the bar itself so that's great if there's a game going on.

I like their service too but took one star off because you have to pay by cash for drinks so you either have to have cash or keep pay extra $2.50 on their ATM machine.
author: Suprita K.

description:
Philosopher's Club is a great little place to catch a game, have a decent priced drink, shoot some pool, or host a Yelp Mix CD swap. 

I like the proximity to the train, which helps keep all of us drunks off the road post pints. 

The decor is cool - check the ceiling (painted by one of the owners), the nostalgic artwork, and the photos galore. The regulars are friendly and welcoming, it's not overly hip - which is a plus - and they have pool tables in the back. Good times all around.
author: Jonathan M.

description:
This is a great bar to chill out and have a reasonably priced drink and some philosophizing.  We had an unusually early dinner so we got to the bar early too, probably shortly after 8pm.  It was kind of funny watching the demographic change as it got later.  When we arrived it was full of folks in their 40's/50's presumably having a drink or two before heading home (they probably had an early dinner also).  As it got later the crowd got younger until it was mostly people in their 30's.  
At any age the crowd was mostly friendly locals having a drink and some conversation.  The place is clean, they have a pool table, the bathrooms suck.  The bartenders are nice and friendly which is pretty typical for a neighborhood type place.  However they also were attentive and quick to take your order and make your drinks which is more rare in a neighborhood bar.
author: David G.

description: Well this was my favorite bar to go to in west portal after work, until the bartender charged me $6 for a rolling rock. I've been here so many times and only been charged $3, when I asked him how much (bartender with shaggy hair) he looked at me straight faced and said $6 like I had idiot written on my forehead. Well I'll start going to McCarthys. And btw they do have a really nice bartender, an older guy really friendly  and easy to talk to
author: Robert F.

description:
Located in West Portal off the Muni station, is a great pub with mainly just locals or mostly friends of the locals heading off to the Giants game. 

Bartenders are always nice, quick to deliver and aren't shy with their drinks. You can play a game of pool in the back or watch some sports on the TV. Great place just to hang out with your friends and enjoy your beverage. Very comfortable pub here, no attitudes or people "looking at you up and down" type pub. 

Also, next door, is Bullshead for a burger :) Can't go wrong!!!
author: Linda L.

description:
Amazing bar with good prices, bartenders, drinks, and patrons! Not too often you find that in a random local bar. Not too big of a place, nor is it too small. The jukebox offers a good variety of music for anyone to enjoy. 

Josh and Sully are amazing. Just so you know, Josh makes the best "Oh Baby, Oh Baby" in town! Ask him to make one for you the next time you're there!

@Emma H.: I'm so sorry, hon, but Josh has left you for me. We are going to cross the equator together to our own island to start our own cult which will eventually dominate the entire world and Mars. :-)

Go to this bar! It's fun, casual and awesome!
author: Rachel S.

description:
This place is garbage. Came here recently with a couple people, two of which were Mexican. From the minute we walked in the female bartender (and everyone else for that matter) made it clear they didn't want us in here. 

Growing up in the Sunset, I was unfortunately made aware of racism toward anyone who wasn't  a white native (I am both). Pretty sad to see it's alive and well here. So if you're into hanging out with knuckle-draggin locals who still think it's 1970 c'mon by. 

No self-respecting person that I know, native or not, would be caught dead here.
author: Tommy T.

description: Fun bar, if you like sports you can always have a fun conversation. They only take cash but have an ATM. Worth a visit
author: Tommy F.

description:
Been coming here for years (and years).

Popped in here as my second stop on a fun night of drinking last Sat night.  Made a bunch of new friends and had some really great and interesting conversations.  Josh the bartender rocked as always...fun times...how can anyone not like this place?

Close to taxis and the Muni Metro too...a definite plus.

From here, it was on to Park 77 or The Riptide...that night, I chose The Riptide.
author: Roy N.

description:
What a wonderful little pub!  This place is completely unpretentious, and the patrons are the average Joe.  The bartenders were completely friendly, there are little tables for groups, a pool table in the back, and a jukebox in the corner.  That's all I need for a great night with some close friends.

Note: This is a *cash only* bar, but there is an ATM inside with a $2.50 fee.

This will become a regular spot for me!
author: Jason F.

description:
This is the type of bar where you don't intend to get shit-hammered at, but it sort of happens anyway because you're too lazy to leave or it's drizzling outside [and this Asian doesn't do rain. Sorry bro.]. 

It's your typical bar. You know - drinks, pool table, music, and the few slam pieces here and there. Not a bad pit stop if you're going to be getting off of the L Line Muni anyway.
author: Michael L.

description:
This friggin' place rocks! Ok, honestly it's come around a lot and sometimes it's more crowded than I'm comfy with  - but it's not what it used to be (a dumpy dive is being nice). New owners in recent years have turned this into a great place to simply have a good time. If I'm there and it is crowded I'll still stay because sometimes in life you can't have perfect but less than perfect is still really good! Plus, with any business with success you get crowds. Can't have it all!

It's a great great neighborhood spot. No overboard fancy schmancy crap. I don't need that. Hopefully neither should you (ok, sometimes it can be nice). 

The owners and staff are really nice. In the last year or so one of the owners (an artist) did a friggin' awesome mural of philosophers that's on the ceiling. Totally dig it!

Great place to watch games (TV's), they have a bunch of football helmets above the liquor shelf and other sports stuff (like Giants bobbleheads). And as others mentioned, great place to pregame (especially for the Giants - just hop on the streetcar!)

They have enough beer on tap (if 4 or 5 choices isn't enough for you, sorry mister beer snob!) and wine if you're in that mood. And liquor - check. Oh, cash only, but there is an atm - and also multiple big bank atm's within 2 blocks (walk quick in the fog and get back inside for the warmth!)

A great place to catch up with friends or even if you go in by yourself (hey, that need happens for a lot of us from time to time) you'll feel welcome. And warmed up by the charm despite the thick fog outside on many nights!

And yeah it is a spot frequented by locals - but if you're not a native still come, there are plenty of nice locals who go here who like welcoming folks who haven't lived in SF their whole life or are visiting.

It's a friendly place. And that's why it just simply rocks! Also one of the owners who bartends very frequently wears shorts - even on many foggy nights. Awesome!!!!!!!!

If I asked more of a neighborhood bar I'd hate myself!
author: Emmet M.

description:
Basically Cheers minus all the fun people.

Pluses: 
A set of Liars dice (but only one)
Two game machines
Pool in the back 
Great Bartender

Minuses:
Nothing all that interesting about the décor
No booths, only stools
Jukebox doesn't have some great hits (and it's online too)
People smoke directly in front of the door

Mainly, this is the most fitting A-OK that I've ever done.
author: Meg T.

description:
I would designate this bar the best of West Portal. It's an older crowd, mostly sports oriented, but they are friendly folk and the drinks are cheap(ish). They have a single pool table and a golf game and an interesting mural on the ceiling. 

If you're in the area stop by.
author: Jordan P.

description:
OMG! What a great time. My wife and I wandered in and stayed for hours. We actually got comped several drinks! When does that happen anymore?AND a bag of fritos. 

Bartenders, Josh and Sully were a blast. The ceiling mural of philosophers is epic. Get them to give you the story behind it. The drinks are well made and generously poured. No measured portions here. Drink here and get the Bullshead restaurant next door to deliver a juicy steak right to the bar. You won't be sorry. 

Best bar I've been to in years.
author: Jason J.

description: One of the best neighborhood bars! It's a lil gem. The Cheers of West Portal! Deb is amazing, as is Scully! Josh is a great compliment to this team! All and all, they make a UNICORN TWERK!
author: Unicorn T.

description:
We stopped by here before heading to the Giants game because it was right by the West Portal station. I think it'd be a great place to pregame for the game before getting on the bus. It'd even be a great place to watch multiple games at once! They had 4 TV screens with different channels on each. That way, you can see many of the baseball games or football games that are on. 

The bartender was super friendly! He cracks a few jokes and talks to all the customers. He's pretty prompt and aware of who needs something. 

The prices are pretty decent. Beers on tap were $5 each. A shot of Jameson was $6. I don't know if it was cheaper for happy hour (we were there at 6pm ish) but I'd definitely want to stop by here the next time I park at West Portal before a Giants game!
author: Connie Y.

description:
I feel that the West Portal area is one of the nicest, yet under appreciated neighborhoods in SF. I really should spend more time in this area since they are so many gems, and the Philosopher's Club is one of them. 

My friend, Amy, recommended PC, and total props to her for doing so. 
We walked in and literally a minute later decided to order some snacks from Bulls Head next door to bring back to PC. *BTW, I love when bars allow outside food to be brought inside their establishment*
As we walked out, the bartender and friends at bar waved and said bye to us, and we assured them that we'd return. Maybe, they thought that we were scared off by this bar or something, BUT that was so far from the truth. 
We were totally vibing this place, which was clean with cool interior, pool tables in the back, and flat screen TVs (with the Warrior game on) throughout the bar, etc.,  OK, so it also helped that there were some cuties hanging out, too. Duh, we'd be stupid to not come back! 

So, after returning with fries and mini corn dogs from next door, we sit at a table close to the lone video game. Chowing on our snacks (which were tasty treats), drinking our brewskies (which were oh so refreshing), and soaking in the PC vibe (which we were totally diggin' as while girl chatting, we were also checking out the eye candy and Warriors game) :) 

Bartender was friendly and knew many of the patrons, who seem to be a mix of young and old, and definitely locals. This is the type of bar that reminds me of Cheers - friendly and not stuffy; no frills but not exactly divey; and yes, where everybody knows your name (and if they don't, they will soon enough)! 

Unfortunately, my first PC experience was cut short since we had to head back to the Empire for the flick. Rest assured, I'll return to spend more than just an hour and one round of drinks at PC. I predict a fun, crazy drunken eve here in the near future! :)
author: Gill C.

description: Little hole in the wall place. The staff remembers you as and knows what you'll have to drink before you even have to ask.   They have a nice paintings and murals. If you love giants and football that is a down to earth bar to go to.
author: Yelp Bunny Advocate G.

description: The owner; Richard Donahue (Dicky) is handsome, very smart, very friendly, generous and has the the charisma to maintain all of the SF natives. On holidays everyone that has moved away gathers there and takes over. It is the best drinking hole with great prices.
author: Kerrie K.

description:
One of the most Original names for a bar in SF. Love the location. Love the bar. Great neighborhood bar and wonderful junction to catch muni downtown or have that drink getting off the train coming home from work.

My image of the bar is the black and white photo.
author: William M.

description: Great bar, was here on a Saturday with friends and we enjoyed many Irish Coffees.  Wonderful place to catch a game too on the many screens.  Just a really relaxed atmosphere and lots of friendly regulars.  Looking forward to coming back for some Monday Night Football.
author: Kristine K.

description:
Confucius? Nope. Sartre? Non. Nietzsche? Nein. 

Regular SF folk? Yup. Pool table? Uh-huh. Sports fans? Check. Drunk lady falling off stool? Yes, last time I was there.

Utilitarian bar and that's all (maybe John Stuart Mill would appreciate it).
author: Art O.

description:
Crazy mural on the celling featuring  some unidentifiable philosophers?  Check!
Pool table that needs a vacuuming and whose pockets have velcro instead of felt to make sure that your ball hovers at the pocket instead of falling in?
Check!
Tons of TVs turned to different channels?
Check!
All purple women's room with dawn dishwashing soap to wash your hands?  
Check!
If you're looking a place that won't be too crowded to enjoy a drink in a divey atmosphere, you've found it.
author: She-Ra ..

description:
This is a typical townie bar that you would be likely to find in any town in the U.S. It almost feels out of place for San Francisco, but in a good way. It's not trying to be different, or even to get you to go there. I get the feeling there are a ton of regulars. But that's not to say that you won't be welcomed as a newbie. The bartender seemed more than happy to have us there when he found out we were new to the neighborhood. 

The people were all great. Really good, solid people. Including the fantastic bartender and the lady sitting next to us, who ended up being our BFF4LYFE. 

It's a great little dive bar, but not the kind of place you want to take someone who's visiting. It's better for a quick wind-down drink after work right before hopping on the Muni at West Portal.
author: Kristen B.

description:
Nice chill bar in west portal. I've been coming here for ages for Sunday night beers and pool and have met some very interesting cats.

When I think "friendly neighborhood bar" I think "Philly's club!". 

Shout out to Josh, who is just awesome and has impeccable taste in music. He even let me and my friend pick a few songs one night. It was awesome. 

I come for the hef, and stay for the atmosphere :)
author: Nikki H.

description: I Come here once in a while and have always had good service. Bartenders are friendly and get to you right away on busy nights.
author: Zack K.

description:
This place can be AWESOME or not so good depending on when you go/who's in there/the bartender....Some of my cronies say no one selects Philospohers as a destination...it's where you end up at the beginning/end of an evening...when Muni meltsdown...when you're too liquor'd up to go anywhere else and you don't to run into an ex at Joxer's or The Dubliner...well, who can argue with that logic??

Anyway, I stopped by last evening after hopping off Muni (literally) and thought, why not?  So to close out the evening, enjoyed a Bailey's and Coffee...dee-lish on a cold, West Portal evening (as most are...we're in the Fog Belt this side of town baby)   

The crowd was subdued and the barman was hilarious!! Challenged us to Liar's Dice and even though we lost (it's Lent afterall (~_~) he bought us a round a drinks! How do you like 'dem apples? (very much nodding vigorously)     We even got to play a quick game of pool (amazing, usually it's backed up with games for 2 hours)  

All in all, a great way to wrap up the evening!

5 STARS for last night's visit,   4 Stars as a mean average of all other visits!!
author: Karen S.

description:
Solid neighbourhood bar, right next to the West Portal stop.  Come here for a low-key pint with buddies, or with family visitors, or just to sit at the bar and strike up conversation.

Sully is about the friendliest bartender in all of SF.  I mean, he's a spaz, but in a funny, good way.  Also, he's originally from Buffalo, so if you're from the East Coast, you'll enjoy talking with him about the Old World.
author: Dmytro A.

description:
The name is much cooler than the bar. Only ended up here after the MUNI effed me. 
Nothing good on tap. Not as cheap as it should be but, I wasn't drinking canned bud light like the rest of the regulars were.

Would only come back here ironically.
author: kristen l.

description:
The bartender with the glasses, tall, skinny, in his 40's, is very pompous.

The guy isn't even from San Francisco and he had the nerve to butt into our conversation and tell a 5th generation born and raised San Franciscan that he wasn't a REAL San Francisco because he didn't go to high school in San Francisco. 

What kind of establishment employs someone like that. Ignorant and closed minded on many fronts.

I'll make sure everyone I know doesn't go to Philosophers Club on West Portal. 

Instead, I'll send them to Portal's or Joxer
author: Mike S.

description:
Great little bar, right around the corner from West Portal muni station.

Worth the hike from anywhere int he city to catch a Giants game. Full of cheerful, genuine fans!
author: Christian K.

description:
Solid neighborhood bar.  

Good place to either start or stop at on the Taraval Crawl.  I also love this bar for when I'm riding the L home all late and then MUNI decides to go and fuck me over by turning the L I'm riding into a K (Really MUNI?  Why you got to play me like that?) and there isn't another L coming for like 26 minutes.  No worries.  Lets just go get a beer or two at Philosophers and check when it's coming on my phone.  

Definitely beats sitting in the MUNI station all sober.
author: Chelsea C.

description:
Ah, the 'ol Philly Club. No where better to sip some drinks, and blackout. A place to chit chat with an old friend, meet some new ones over a game of pool, and become obnoxiously wasted. Cheap drinks and thrills. 

Either you become incapacitated and stay through 'til Call, or you stumble onto the MUNI platform and find yourself in the SF everyone else knows. 

Philly Club is a staple for me- wrapped in nostalgia; probably the place i will grow old in, come out smelling of gray and stale booze. Worse fates have unraveled.

Added daytime perk: If you're out drinking in the day or afternoon here and wet your appetite, Sub Center is next door. Munchie-fucking-heaven.
author: Talib J.

description:
This place used to be a lot cooler before it was remodeled.  I love a dive bar, but they should remain just that--divey.   Not that it still doesn't qualify--it just moved itself away from the cool kind.

I used to go here a lot  with a then boyfriend.  I worked in the Inner Sunset/lived on the Peninsula and we hung out a lot in the city.
Philosopher's Club was a great place to chill, play pool, have a couple of drinks and smooch. 

Fast forward a couple years and it isn't as cool.  very sad.
author: Katharine A.

description: This place is dead on the weekends.  Also, there are old creepy guys at the end of the bar that will talk your ear off, or hit on you (depending on your gender).  Skip.
author: Bill H.

description:
When i first heard of a bar called Philosophers Club, i knew i had to check it out.  I mean, thats an awesome name.  It makes me think of a place where great thinkers would come and meet to converse the meaning of life and get wasted at the same time.

This is a local neighborhood bar.  Located right next to the west portal tunnel in a pretty peaceful area.  I like the location as it doesnt get too crowded here.  And i usually head here right before i go home.  It has a pool table, jukebox and a couple of TV's, plus the bartenders are friendly and welcoming.  

Need to ponder some deep thoughts, then come here.  Thats what i do.  Well that and drink!
author: Terence P.

description: If you like bars that are reminiscent of places in that are located on a side street in a crummy part of Baltimore, you have found your spot. I love this bar, although I can only take 2-3 hours and have to leave..
author: Jim B.

description:
What can I say about the Philospher's Club? It's divey, which makes it stick out in the uber pretentious neighborhood of West Portal. I love dive bars, so I'm all in! 
Josh makes a strong Whiskey and Sour. I normally try not to drink whiskey as it makes me act so completely crazy. I mean, much more so than usual. After two (maybe three?), I decided to try and make out with my ex which was the WORST IDEA POSSIBLE. Nevermind the fact I'd been drinking beer all day, I'm blaming the whiskey!
The bartenders are awesome and so are the people that frequent the place. Everyone was so kind after I freaked the fuck out, that I don't even feel embarrassed about going back, eventually. 
I almost want to take away a star considering it is so hard to get to. I have to take cabs home, but in a way, that adds to the appeal. It's the kind of place that keeps it's mystery, as I can't stumble in/out every night. 
You can play pool there too, which I'd do if it weren't even more mortifying for me than my previously stated antics.
author: Jenny B.

description: Coming here was random even for me. The spot had  great bar and good crowd. The place is small but the workers new everybody coming into the door. Because they knew everybody coming after to around West Portal to drink after work. It's a typical townie bar. I heard about coming here during the day but I haven't made it out there yet. It's an older crowd. So this place doesn't have the patrons hitting on the servers all night long.
author: Matt B.

description:
I remember when I was young and impressionable and believed what people said. Until my dreams were crushed with the awful truth. 

Like when I realized that "pretty ugly" meant just plain ugly instead of more pretty than ugly. 

Or when I found out that Slim Jims are not a diet food, but just the opposite, and that it is nearly impossible to "snap" into one. 

Then there was the day I found out the tooth fairy was none other than my parents keepsake drawer. I was extremely confused as to how the drawer got under my pillow and collected the teeth until the tooth drawer belief was also snatched from my imagination by my older sister who told me it was all made up. 

Hot dogs? Pppffffhhh. Not made from real dogs!

Over the years I learned not to believe everything I was told. There was some dribble about growing up and school of hard knocks and facing reality.

Thanks for toughening me up to the real world, robbing me of my childhood and taking unicorns and fairies away from me at the young age of two. I guess I am supposed to be ready for anything now right? Well, guess what??? 

I am not ready to accept that a place with the name Philosophers Club is not really an elite club and is not full of philosophers. Unless old drunk pervy men are philosophers and dank bars that smell of stale beer and sling strong drinks with inconsistent service now qualify as clubs. 

I am also not ready to accept that unicorns and fairies cease to exist.
author: Drue C.

description:
Philosopher's club is a typical dive bar/sports bar. Great place to come and just chill with friends.

Cheap drinks, cool bartenders. Atmosphere was A-OK. Just typical. They have a jukebox, kinda lame, I should of brought my guitar and played better songs. But overall, the place was not bad....for typical west portal district. Also, they have pretty neat pictures of San Francisco History ranging from landmarks to major league players. Idk. Something to gaze at when you're chilling with groups of people.
author: Adam C.

description:
For being just an "average" bar this place is actually really, really nice on the inside. I think they renovated the place not too long ago. Very clean, very nice, very friendly locals, just don't expect to walk into a jumping, busy bar. This place is a locals bar and typically pretty quiet. 

I usually don't go drinking around the Portal area. And by the way, what the hell is up with the "Portal" moniker? Makes me think I'm going to wind up in the negative zone going over there. Portal's not a neighborhood name, it's a thing that evil robots get sucked into. 

Anyway, It's nice bar where you have a beer and talk sports with the friendly bartender, the kinda place you'd spend a lot of time at on a Thursday if you lived around the corner.  You'd only want to be here on a Friday night if you were all about low-key, which sometimes, is a good thing.
author: Andy A.

description:
The Portal get's no love from Yelp, so I will represent for the WP. The Philosopher's Club is a fantastic neighborhood bar right on the Portal. Have a great night:
- playing pool (missing every shot and blaming the stick)
- watching the game (crying with neighbor over the niners demise)
-talking local neighborhood politics(Bob let's his damn mutt crap on my lawn every night!) 
You can then stumble home and send off your friends off to their downtown destination via the L Taraval. And if that's not enough, the drinks are reasonable and the crowd is genial when boozed.
author: Phil M.

description:
"Where did you go for St. .Patty's Day?" countless friends inquired.
"To the Philly!" I replied with a smile and a sense of SF pride.
"What?! WHY???" Was the most common response.

Because I didn't want to repeat last year's St. Patty's where I ended up walking miles in high heels searching for a cab at 3am in North Beach. Eff that man - give me West Portal, where there is public transportation, street parking, and no need to don the heels! 
I really felt damn comfortable in the Philly - not "pajamas and glasses" comfortable, but "not worried about getting a little loud" comfortable. There *may* have been some singing around the juke-box. There was plenty of Bud Light and no sneers from the bartender when I ordered a round of ten. The crowd was wonderfully local - none of those bridge and tunnelers that were snagging my cabs in NB the previous year. 
All-in-all a perfect place to meet after work or on your favorite drinking holiday!
author: Jessa B.

description: A no frills divey bar in a good way. If you want a chill night and you're on your way downtown or you don't want to venture too far away from the neighborhood, this bar's a great place.
author: Jay L.

description:
Somehow this has become a quasi-LSU bar. Which makes it right up my alley. And because other LSU alums go there and buy me drinks (not the douchey ones who attend the alumni sponsored events), and they have an LSU helmet, and piss Cal fans off by putting the sound of the LSU games on in favor of the Cal game, I'm giving it four stars. There are always actual footall fans who know what they are talking about, including the bartender, and tell me things that even I, in my infinite football wisdom, weren't aware of. I like to learn as I drink. 

The minus star is for having to talk to excessively drunk old guys and running into either coworkers of my parents or people I went to HS with. 

Plus, even as a dive bar, you should have seen this bar BEFORE they cleaned it up. It was awful. Now, it's pretty nice, if not exactly classy. But if I wanted classy I would go to the Marina (no, actually, not on my life). Oh, also you can order Bullshead from next door and eat it at the bar and that's all good. And they have chips. Because I am for sure one of those people that gets hungry when she drinks and having easy access to a six month old bag of fritos makes me happy.
author: Lisa M.

description:
Homey, comfortable bar with awesomely nice bartenders, Josh and Jesse I think.  (I was drunk.)  My BF said the place reminded him of the bars back home in WI.  Lots more men than girls in there.  Younger crowd than the old timers at Joxer Daly's but older crowd than the regulars at Dubliner.  Good mix.  

Last night we went, and it was chill and alot of fun.  There was a group of girls in there that looked like chubby versions of the crowd you see in the Marina, and then when a few girls walked in that looked like actual girls from the Marina, after a few stare downs, they walked right out.  I felt bad for them since I actually have been accused of being a Marina girl too, but this particular night I knew we would be doing the casual thing so I wasn't all decked out= ie. I fit in last night with the crowd.  

Either way, if you don't go in all dolled up and with your Gucci bag, and with an attitude you will have fun here.  How can you not with such a chill vibe and cool bartenders??
author: Denise B.

description:
Dim lighting and televisions everywhere.  Not at all conducive to good conversation.  

On this particular night, the place was dominated by a loud, obnoxious group of meat heads.  One of them tried to make it seem like the place was bumpin' by yelling out "Yeahhhh!!!!!!!!" every few minutes.

We had our drinks and left.
author: Chris Q.

description:
So, I made the mistake of coming here one night and not being tanked all ready... probably why that night sucked.

So I made the mistake of coming here one night and not all ready being an established regular... probably why that night sucked.

So, I made the mistake of coming here one night and ordering a Long Island:  tiny glass, decent pour, hefty fee.  Wasted too much money getting tanked... probably why that night sucked.

So, I made the mistake of wearing my Yankees hat here one night, bartender gave me shit service (fair enough, I'd give him shit if he was in a Sox cap)... probably why that night sucked.

Hmm, maybe I just made the mistake of coming here at all.

Unless you have to, don't do your drinking on West Portal in general.
author: Matt R.

description:
Aww, this place isn't so bad. Do you really think philosophers really exist these days?  Even if they did, they wouldnt be able to afford a drink at a bar.

Anyway, this is a local dive bar, and most of the people that come here live within a 5-block radius.  It's definitely not a place to pick up on anyone, but just to chill with neighbors and old friends.  There's a pool table, a juke box, and the drinks are made well here.  

4 stars because it reminds me of home, but 2 stars if it was located anywhere else.
author: Audacity L.

description:
Good neighborhood bar, but always the last stop on our West Portal Pub Crawl.  It's cool that it's right next to the muni station, too.   They have a pool table and there's usually nobody there who can beat me.  

Drinks are cheap.  I usually run into kids from gradeschool here.  And it's right next to my favorite samwich shop and my favorite burger spot.  Check out Subs Center and Bulls Head for sure.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
I wanted to have a scotch before my movie.  The Philosopher had the right single malt, sports on a 50 inch, good conversation or not , and good burgers next door, or sandwiches depending on whether you turn left or right as you walk out the door.  Sometimes, the burger lady brings the burger to me.

I feel warm here.  Comfortable.  Invisible as my wont, or involved.

I'm going there now...
author: Gregory P.

description:
*** Updated 8/19/07 ***

The last stop on the West Portal Pub Tour.

Actually I had already been to the Philosopher's Club before, since it's the closest bar to my house (not counting the Miraloma Club), it has an awesome name and a cool sign, and a neat location right next to the Muni tunnel.   But Philosopher's Club is a total misnomer.  There's no philosophers here, just a very random mix of Muni-refugees.  And anyway, it's now clear that Portals Tavern is the rightful jewel of the WP bar scene--it has real character.   P Club, along with Dubliner and Joxer Daly, is just another one of West Portal's overly generic bars.
author: Wes M.

description:
I want to give it more stars, if only for improvement.

Wandered into this place like maybe 1999.  REALLY divey.  No decorations, no atmosphere.

Went in on purpose about a month ago to meet a friend.  They have totally remodelled, er um totally "modelled".  The place seemed cheery in a bar kind of way.  Somehow I felt like we had to earn our place at the bar, as we had to keep giving the barkeep the eye to get him to bring us some more drinks.  I guess it all evened out in the end.  There were a lot of locals there, which means it was definitely not a scene.  Fine with me.
author: Nelson W.

description:
I used to live in the inner sunset and drove by this bar every time that I drove to or from SF. I've always wondered about it. in my mind, this place would be all historic looking on the inside, with lots of armchairs and people smoking pipes. people would be sitting around and playing chess with each other, or lazily leafing through thick books while they drank cognac. possibly a person or two inside would be wearing a monocle or maybe even a top hat. who knows.

well, my dreams of this place were shattered when I finally went there. instead of the philosopher's club, they should have named it "Nondescript Bar" or possibly "Just Some Bar". or, I guess they could have named it after the very weak drinks that they pour. none of us were very impressed by this place. oh, and they had a bunch of big screen TVs which just really don't seem to belong in a "philosopher's club". the only thing this place really had going for it was that it was pretty much the only bar in the area. I guess if you are in the West Portal and are stranded, this could be your local bar. luckily, we weren't stranded, so we left after 2 drinks.

(my resolution this year is to visit 50 new bars in SF.  read about it at: http://fiftybars.thisisvlad.com)
author: vlad k.

description:
Not a bad spot, considering the area.  It's close to the MUNI and therefore, a good spot to meet up with friends at the beginning of the night.  Grab a few drinks and hop back on the MUNI.  

Drank some Glenlivet neat. 12-year.  Easy, simple.
author: Tracy H.

description: This place is great for a drink on the way home after work. The drinks are cheap and strong
author: Bumble B.

description: I was surprised this place was packed on a Friday night.  As I recall, it was empty the last time I was there.  What a place to watch locals, students and older people, all having a low-key drunken time.
author: Jenn C.

description:
The definition of a "meh" bar. 

When I first got to college and didn't know anyone, I decided to try the bar scene here, see if I could meet people. The Philosopher's Club sounded like a good place to start with its proximity to campus.

Damn was I wrong.

The ambiance is very much "old farts only," anyone I talked to shrugged me off or assumed I was cougar hunting (not my thing, at ALL), and the bartender gave off this desperate "stay here, have some drinks, we're REALLY TRYING to get some new blood in" vibe. 

Drinks are good, and he ended up pouring me a freebie so I don't want to seem ungrateful. Still, the people that go there don't want me and mine, so it's hard to wedge the college element in.
author: Tyler B.

description: Good dive bar with a coin operated, slightly felt-torn pool table tucked away in the back. The mural of philosophers juxtaposed against ESPN SportsCenter is a mind-bender.
author: brewgirl b.

description: Popped in here while waiting on the street car. It had a neighborhood feel and I was welcomed in as if I come in all the time. After running into friends of mine I did feel like a regular. Good prices and fast service!
author: Kris M.

description:
Philosopher's is actually one of my Favorite bars. 
Since West Portal is so close to SF State, all the bars are filled with children- literally, all the students (21 or not) head to Dubliner to drink. Luckily, Philosopher's is at the far end, and kinda hidden. The regulars are in their late 30s and older, the Bartenders are super nice, and the drinks are cheap!
FYI: Cash only
author: Jane S.

description:
Just ok... nothing too great.... 2.5 stars really.

First time I went here,ok crowd but a bit young!

Second time, went with by boyfriend and friends and almost got into a brawl with some of the youngsters.

Overall, ok but nothing great.
author: Michi R.

description: My new favorite bar to day drink at. We popped in after eating next door for a beer. And ended up staying for the next 5 hours. Drinks are decently priced. The old-timer behind the bar is a total sweetheart. Pool table and jukebox. We discovered they had a small outdoor area, which is where we spent most of our time. After about 3 hours of drinking, we ended up getting a round on the house :) Seems to be one of those"where everybody knows your name" bars. The same people were occupying the bar when we walked in, as when we left. And their whole wall is a tribute to the Giants winning the series. You gotta love that :)
author: Mary B.

description: Ok environment. Music wasn't too loud so you could actually hold a conversation. They had more beers in bottles than on tap. But it's close to my house & cheap enough. Also right next to West Portal station so you don't have to worry about driving drunk. Don't understand why all the bars in this area are cash only, kinda sucks.
author: M S.

description: The Philly is a San Francisco staple. Friendly,fast service, great pours, fair prices, nice eclectic crowd. Yeah, that just about covers it. I work across town at Dirty Trix Saloon, the Philly is the perfect place to have a relaxing "final-final" on my way home.
author: Lee P.

description:
No!
I wanted books on shelves. Lots of books.
And big leather type chairs and maybe some type of smallish fireplace.And old men types in tweed discussing or how about philosophizing about. . . .stuff. Blahhh this place is just average, and there are no books on shelves.
The locals are nice and the bartender is friendly.
I spotted myself fast forward 30 years in the form of a cute brown skinned lady pushin' 55. In a bling'd out sweater set and tattooed eyebrows. Sipping martinis and quietly commanding attention ofthe the older handsome regulars. I turned to my date and asked: 
"So with all the drinking I do, Is it your opinion that as I age I will one day be as cute as that 'mature bar patron'? 'Cause you know I like to think that acupuncture offsets the negative effects of drinking. And all this rum I drink I'm sure this will help me become well preserved in the future."
"Sure" he replied with a sweet smile.
Good boy.
Not bad, not great. But,I'm partial to The Dubliner a few blocks away. . .
author: Kia B.

description:
West Portal is a principal shopping street for much of southwestern San Francisco, California, and is also considered a neighborhood itself. Named for the western terminus of the Muni tunnel beneath Twin Peaks that opened in 1918, the street (West Portal Avenue) and adjacent district is still dominated by the frequent trundlings of the three Muni Metro lines (K, L and M) that emerge from the subway to run in the street median. The ride in the subway from West Portal to downtown/Union Square is about fifteen minutes.

West Portal lies directly adjacent to several larger San Francisco neighborhoods: the affluent and lushly verdant Forest Hill and St. Francis Wood neighborhoods on the east and south, Parkside (a southern sub-district of the Sunset District) on the north, and at the western end of the Avenue, Lakeshore Village and Merced Manor. The residential areas of the West Portal neighborhood, like several of the adjacent districts, are unusual for San Francisco in that the homes are often detached, albeit with small yards. The frequent fog helps keep the area green in the usually rainless summer months, and on a clear day, the park above the tunnel provides a view of the Marin Headlands and the Farallon Islands in the Pacific.

In addition to the streetcar tunnel, West Portal's landmarks include a large movie theater, a library, a school, churches (including the prominent West Portal Lutheran Church and School), many good restaurants (Fuji, Roti, (Old Krakow[1]), El Toreador, Xiao Loong, Fresca, Fuji, Bursa, Spiazzo), bars (Portal's Tavern[2], Philosophers' Club, The Dubliner, Joxer Dailys), a bookstore (BookShop West Portal ([3]), drugstores (Walgreens and Rite Aid), markets, coffeeshops (Starbucks, Pete's Cafe, Greenhouse), a bakery (West Portal Bakery), professional offices, a video rental store (Diamond Videos), and many beauty salons. There is also a childcare located in the west portal area ABC Childcare which has been around since 1988. Despite the semi-recent appearances of larger chain stores, the many unique neighborhood shops give the area a distinctly smaller-city, "retro" charm. The West Portal Muni Metro Station is located at the entrance to the Muni tunnel at the northern end of West Portal Ave.

I have a wooden token from this bar that entitles me to 1 free drink of any make or measure. hahaaha  I will never use it.  I like the Dubliner down the street but it does not have that much history.

Infodiva hiccup here...  I am not a morning drinker!!! I am going to organize a West Portal Yelp Pub-Crawl soon.  94132 OMI yadda
author: Infodiva B.

description: One of the most laid-back, unpretentious watering holes in the City, you'll find this place just beyond the mouth of the West Portal MUNI station. It's a little cleaner than it used to be (and I'm not sure that's a good thing), but still just a great neighborhood bar that's perfect for bellying up for a couple. Also, if you and a small posse of friends pop in on a weeknight, you can practically own the joint.
author: Gregor G.

description:
So the other evening, I got a call from a belligerently drunk very good friend of mine demanding my presence at Edinburg Castle (on Geary in the Loin) in 30 minutes. Considering that I was already drunk after a very long & taxing week (shit, try THREE weeks), I obliged. Grudgingly.

I grabbed my frequently rowdy roommate & pitched the idea. Predictably he was all in. Within about 40 minutes, we were sipping on some dranks at the bar with a few of my co-workers (who just so happened to be there) when my buddy staggered in with about 25 wasted kids. Turns out they were riding around town in a Mexican Drunk Bus (yes, that's the official name), & my friend was in NO SHAPE to continue. I made him drink a large glass of ice water, bought a few slices of pizza next door, & sent him home in a cab.

Before I knew what was happening, I found myself being ushered onto this bus of amazing fools against my will & better judgement. Within minutes, we were climbing fast towards Twin Peaks blasting Neutral Milk Hotel. Half-empty cans of Tecate which someone -- or several someones -- had thought prudent to set on the floor of the bus earlier in the night, had tipped over & were trickling beer down the aisles & clinking against the sides of the bus as we rounded the big bend up, up up. The lights of the city shimmered like broken glass below us & stretched all the way out to the Bay. A drunk girl was performing small but dangerous gymnastic feats on the handlebars attached to the ceiling. She swung as the bus shifted, & those of us who weren't completely 'faced started to wear looks of worry, concerned with the ever-increasing probability that a nasty fall was imminent. Half the bus was furiously smoking cigarettes, but really really coolly, like the way James Dean must've smoked when he wanted to act pissed off that everyone was watching him smoke, although that's what he secretly wanted everyone to be doing.

I sat by the window next to rowdy roommate & another friend, half-smiling, half-horrified at this strange predicament. What in the hell are we DOING up here?! An hour ago I was ready to goto bed & now I'm in TWIN PEAKS! Drunk in a bus! With no escape! Listening to amazing (admittedly) music! Surrounded by screaming hipsters at half past midnight! Just a few months ago, I might have enjoyed this a lot more than I was enjoying it at that moment. But I've been finding it a lot harder to draw satisfaction from a fuckoff evening of drunken debauchery.

So, when we came down off the mountain & parked the bus in West Portal outside The Philosopher's Club, I was happy. Partly because this is an old haunt from when I worked at SFSU ("old haunt" meaning "I went there twice & liked it"), but partly because I wanted off that bus.

Lo & Behold, I walked in & saw my old friend Jesse working behind the bar. I've known this dude for quite awhile, & hadn't seen him in probably a year, so it was good to get a nice dose of familiarity out of everything. My $4 Sierra & some good catchup conversation redeemed the night.

Too bad they had to usher us to Amber -- one of my all-time least favorite bars ever -- afterwards. I was in there for 10 minutes & still smelled like cigarette smoke the next morning. Fucking Amber.
author: Pete J.

description:
my inner alky lush screams, review your favorite watering hole ! my outer being says, do you wanna look like a waste ? I side with the alky this time. the Philly's is my centrally located saloon, across from a spectacular nail salon and a crepe place, in between a roaring good burger joint and a sub shop, right up the street from Spiazzo (yum) -- what's not to like ?!?!

the owners are wonderful guys and one barkeep calls me Pretty Lady. do you really expect me to say anything neg about the Philly's ?
author: Prima D.

description:
i used to drink alot (underfuckingstatement of a lifetime). im the idiot at the club drinking remy/hen/goose from the bottle or if im trying to be sofitimacated, dom p through a straw. hmmmmmm fuzzy memory of one bday at fizzies with a bottle of remy in each hand dancing on a table. i think i was clothed, probably.. maybe... mmmm hopefully. drinking is not an activity, its a state of mind...... of course now im being the socially responsible person..... very social drinker....... no more shotssssss before dinner, during and for dessert. 

a little over a decade of over indulging....... man i got some stories.... like the time i took a shower with my clothes on at a house party trying to sober up, or when i jumped through a window, or the time i pissed off a balcony onto people sitting below, on purpose *hey come, on i thought itll be funny, besides the bathroom was ALLL the way inside the house* ........ uggg yeah stories and stories and stories.......

anyways, so the philosophers club is in my hood, right next to sub center. when i wasnt in the mood to drive the extra ten blocks or so to  my usual watering hole, wed stop by here. divey neighborhood joint. dont expect them to make a watermelonextractof21yroldvirgintinis here. first time i ordered grey goose red bull, the bartender looked at me all weird and made the WORST  red goose ive ever had. ahhahahaha. stick to shots and beers. cool mp3 jukebox.

must leave you with story....

so me and my buddy bobs donuts was smoking outside, bsing. this cute white girl comes out and ask for a smoke. 

cute random white girl: hey can i get a smoke

me: sure thing

crwg: got a light:

bd: no prob

random crackhead driving by: *shows us a bag of dog food* hey you guys wanna buy some dog food?

crwg: wtf!?!?!? do i look like a dog?

rcdb: *shows us a bag of chips* how about some chips?

all of us:........... *uncontrolable laughter*

moral of the story..... kids, just say no to drugs.

minus one star for strange bathrooms.
author: Euge L.

description:
Philosophers club was ok. If I could I would give it 2.5 stars, but I have decided to round up. "Meh. I've experience better." and "A-OK" really fit the situation. Yes I enjoyed the atmosphere, the bartender was nice, but over-all it was a lack-luster sort of place. We visited on a Saturday night and it seemed really boring. No one seemed local, or in their place, it was very clean, no seed or any fun. 
If you are looking for a local/fun experience I wouldn't suggest this place. However, if you are looking for a good clean beer without any sort of social interaction this is the bar for you!
It's great for a night that you just don't want to deal with the rest of the world but you still want a draft beer. The prices were decent enough that I will be going back with my friends. Usually we make our own fun, considering the neighborhood local-ness, its a pretty sweet chill spot. Just don't expect wild crazy times or much other than just a plain old beer. :)

Oh, and for $1 you can play pool...
author: Hannah K.

description: I used to go here when beer was my meal of choice.  A dive bar trying to dig itself out of divey-ness amidst the "yuppie-esque" environment of the West Portal neighborhood.  The locals are nice enough, despite the suttle feeling that you're not wanted there (that feeling goes away for the most part - the more you show up).  Filled mostly with Sacred Heart alumni aching to relive their high school glory days, washed up and down on their luck West Portal locals left behind in the dust of what West Portal/San Francisco used to be, young rich bastard children spending their parents' money on booze and billiards.  I used to go here, when the patrons were more down to Earth and the owner was this bad-ass white boy named Chris.  Now it's some old honkeys who took the rap selections off of the jukebox (Bastards!) in search of more "relaxed", less "colored" patrons.
author: Darkie L.

description: I'd heard such good things about this place but I have to admit that the only reason I enjoyed being here was the company I was keeping.  My theatre friends and I got drunk and sang along to the jukebox.  Until they unplugged it, that is.  Then, we spent the rest of our time there observing a suave choad trying to pick up on two cougars simultaneously.  Hope he had a good night!
author: Frankie D.

description: Total dive. Not in the best of ways. unhip, but getting hipper. Weird atmosphere, weird bathrooms. Best place in the city to get ignored by a bartender on purpose. You've got to work for a drink.
author: Alexandra K.

description: i love this little pub. mixed crowds
author: Charlie M.

description: They were so welcoming and at the same time not intrusive.  Even the customers in the bar were great people.  What a groovy place to play pool or spend time with friends.
author: Kelly B.

description:
i love this bar!  i go mostly on sunday's to watch football.  tommy, the owner, is a really nice guy.  the day crowd is full of grey haired men who like to talk about their "glory days."  i don't mean that in a bad way either.  my suggestion is to mozy up to the bar, say hi to tommy and order whatever your heart desires.  i can get a bud and a shot of hornitos for $9-$10 depending on who is bartending.

**they love the giants and 49ers here.  you'll never find a raider game on.  i find that to be a negative since i support all bay area teams.
author: T D.

description: This is a weird place, depending on when you go in you get a different crowd and a different bar tender and there's always kind-of a weird vibe going on. You can definitely smell stale beer throughout but surprisingly the bathrooms are really clean. They have good beer on tap but their mixed drinks, including bloody mary's, never seem to taste right. The biggest bonus is this bar is half a block from the West Portal muni station, so it's a good place to stop before I make the trek home, and they have several TVs with different sporting events playing.
author: Kristin D.

description: Local bar so local it reminds me of my hometown.  Stumble in any night of the week and chances are highly probable that the guy that was sitting at a given bar stool last time you were there, will be in the exact same place.  Great pool table in the back room with plenty of space to shoot and televisions that play the big games.  Drink prices are reasonable for the area and it is literally two seconds away from the West Portal MUNI station for that safe trip home.  Something about this part of town feels like a friendly small town, and the Philosopher's Club embodies those small town traditions.
author: Taylor P.

description: Bar tender was friendly, the atmosphere is chill and the pool table in the back is a-OK. I come here during the week to have a few beers and play a game of pool or 2. It is right next to the westportal station so its super easy to get to!
author: kevin C.

description:
four stars for :
-a sweet ass name
-having anderson valley boont amber on tap! woot! f- yeah!
-cool bartenders
-good prices
-sweet jukebox
-a  really clean toilet
-being within walking distance from my friends house

minus 1 star for:
-the guy who scared the shit out of me
-the guy  who may or may have not puked on the floor. There was puke no doubt. who did  it, well, that still anyone's guess!
author: Caddy M.

description: This place started as a joke between me an my friends, we would always ask each other when there was nothing to do if we wanted to go to Philosophers.  Our curiosity got the best of us. I love me some Philosophers.
author: Liz O.

description: Cool local spot in West Portal to grab some brew.  Bar staff are friendly and next door is a shop that has a slamming terriyaki chicken sandwich.  Very good combo.
author: omar b.

description: I give it three stars for the incredibly friendly bartenders, but the demographic leaves much to be desired.
author: Morence L.

description: A mellow and friendly place to get a beer before catching a movie at the theater around the corner.
author: shoba d.

description: The Philly 's is a great little dive in West Portal. I prefer it to Joxer's or the WPT. It has that neighborhood bar feel, where everyone is separated by 2-3 degrees. I first went into Philly's before the remodel and change of ownership. It used to be dark and depressing. Now it has life and huge TV's to catch the games. The bartenders are quick and friendly. They walk from behind the bar occasionally to either chat it up or grab your empties. Cool spot with a good crowd.
author: Eric B.

description: Good neighborhood bar, older crowd typically but every now and then a wave of college kids stirs the place up. Great service, go Josh (the bar tender)!
author: Perri B.

description:
we went on a sunday morning at 11am (yes, it is OPEN then!) and who was in there? no one under 60 years old except for us. this was the quintessential old man bar if i have ever seen one. scene might not be the same at night, but it had a true neighborhood bar feel. everyone knew each other and were talking together, a couple even brough in breakfast to share with everyone there. it's like Cheers, i guess.

don't take that as a slag to this bar by any means, I LOVED IT for the reasons above!!!! :D
author: ms.kiki g.

description: It did lose its character, but that's what happens yuptimes, and for that matter, what happened to all of West Portal.
author: Mag N.

description: It's a dive and a good one. Humbly sitting arround the corner from MUNI's West Portal station, like so many dive bars the Philosopher's Club is a friendly trough for locals and passerby's alike and a good place to meet before dinner or a movie in West Portal.
author: David D.

description: West Portal's Tunnel bar...anyone just slides up and asks for a beer heads out to the pool table, shoots a set, hits the john and leaves without dealing with drama of fisticuffs, fashionistas, or plastic Steppfordism, then heads back onto light rail system.
author: miriam b.

description: Perfect dive in the West Portal area. Weekends are always full of hipsters, blue collar people, and Giants fans. It's nice and dark if you're into that thing.
author: D M.

description: This is a good example of your local neighborhood bar.  It's a great place to watch games, hang out, order pizza and relax.  It's not  pretentious and  the bartenders are nice.  There's a pool table and 3 or 4 flat screens and dice cups.  It's a dice cup kind of bar!  Put on your t-shirt with the least amount of stains and you'll be dressing up!!!  I like it.
author: John M.

description: I practically lived here in the late 80's early 90's.  Back then it was a huge drug bar, probably still is but I no longer partake.  Definitely a dive full-o working class heroes, mostly Irish boyz from the Parkside/Sunset.  It was better before it was remodeled but I would still stop by if I was in WP (West Portal y'all).  The ladies bathroom used to be painted black, kinda weird.  It's not the same but I have my memories.  A serious drinkers bar.
author: Kristina M.

description: Love the place. The Donahue's & Sully make a great match as owners. This is a great neighborhood bar ! Take it at that. My Samoan, Vietnamese & Guamanian friends have all had a good time. No racists crap as one of the previous yelpers said. IT'S A NEIGHBORHOOD BAR, NOT THE RITZ !
author: Matt D.

description: If you feel uncomfortable hanging out in meat market bars, you would probably like the Philosopher's Club. It's not an exciting place to go "see and be seen." You'll find an unpretentious crowd made up of mostly locals which feels kind of reassuring. And sometimes on a lazy Saturday night, that's all you need.
author: L. Renee D.

description: I used to come here every Monday night in the fall of 2001 through the summer of 2002. I didn't miss one night. During this time the bar was under going a huge face-lift and we used to joke that the theme of the bar was that it was supposed to look almost done. I have a lot of fond memories of shooting pool with my old roomate Dave and playing the jukebox. I played that thing so much I knew selections by heart. They have the internet jukebox now which I'm a big fan of but I do miss Bryan the bartender putting in his own mixes. I miss Bryan a lot too, he was a real cool guy who used to take me back near the fire place and smoke me out. I remember the final Monday night we had with our "gang" before Dave and the other exhange students moved back to London. It was a great night! After they closed the bar they let us stay and drink and dance the night away while the rest of West Portal was swallowed by 3AM summer fog. This was the first bar I went to on a regualr basis after I turned 21 so I essentially learned about bar culture and how to drink here ("Jim Bean Black and a bottle of Bud please, Bryan").I have a lot of sentimentality for this old joint and I suspect I always will.
author: Benji T.

description: what's up with the red-faced, pugnacious fat-asses with the attitudes in this place? don't you know that the bartender isn't going to save you from a righteous ass-whipping if you elbow people in the chest who just wanna buy a drink? and your leering at every woman that walks by you is just an invitation for a loud & painful enough slap to wake you from your stupor? damn, and I was just starting to like this place, too. at least the jukebox is decent.
author: Chris C.

description: i'd rather go here than pretty much any other bar in west portal, better staff, and usually a little bit less rowdy of a crowd. sometimes it can get a bit retarded on saturday and friday night, but it's still pretty mellow regardless. sometimes you can get some pretty loud groups of high school sports fans, i dont know what thats all about, but thats really the only complaint i have. oh, and the always present loud stumbling drunks girls.
author: Jeannine S.

description: Why you wanta playa hate on me... The philosophers club a few years back used to be a very scary place.  When I was in grammar school we used to go to Subs next door on our half days and stare at the low lives that used to crawl out of that place looking like they have never seen the light of day, and when I say never, I mean NEVER!  But by some miracle a very nice man by the name of Tommy Donohue decided to clean this place up and give it a second chance.  For me, its close to home.  The bartenders are really friendly and I always end up seeing someone I knew growing up. Some nights I have to admit it gets a little too crowded and annoying.   Besides this, there are great places to eat next door, Subs Center and Bullshead, if you are looking for some grub.  They also have nice flat screen TVs to watch the Giants or Niner game.  Although it is not my absolute favorite bar, I always find myself here after Thanksgiving dinner or even Christmas.
author: Micaela M.

description: Good neighborhood bar.  It's a quiet neighborhood and this is a relatively basic pub but a great place to meet a few friends, catch a game on the (multiple) tvs and grab a beer.  I've never been there when it's been extremely busy but the bar tender has always been very friendly as well.
author: Barry K.

description: dive bar. lotsa locals. young and old. nice bartenders.  i met a guy named 'hot' here. all in all - always a good time.
author: Rachel S.
